bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 29, 1875

div1.p: Reed writes to Emilie Lawrence concerning irony. He notes that there was a delay in receiving her letter.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 29, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Sept. 29th, 75.

div1.p:
Since you were
so very prompt(?) in answering
my last letter, I cannot
find it in my heart to wait
till tomorrow to reply- Monday
went by and no letter from
you- Tuesday came, & still not
a word! I had begun to think
that perhaps, the widow had
frowned on the ancient Galen,
and so driven him to bask
in your smiles. Or mayhap,
the charming Prof. Martin
was warbling sweet strains
in your attentive ear- Num-
erous fancies presented them-
selves to my excited imagin-
ation- As fast as one was
banished, another was ready
to take its place, till, at last,
my thoughts were heaped in
dire confusion- It would be
useless, besides affording you
too much pleasure in the nar-
ration, to tell you of the number
of visions I had, all of which
resulted in your being borne
away by some more fortun-
ate suitor, while I was left
alone & friendless to weep over
my unhappy fate. To speak of
these more fully I forbear,
since an excess of joy might
do hurt to your well-balanced
faculties. Moreover the rehear-
sal of my repeated defeats
could but add to my chagrin.
These, and other potent reasons,
which I might adduce, prevail
upon me to remain silent.
At last, when my cup of grief
was overflowing, & my store
of patience exhausted to its
lowest ebb; and whilst I
was sitting before a win-
dow, with woeful countenance,
viewing my deserted scalp,
from which the last hair had
just disappeared, (its prede-
cessors having been plucked
out the by press of much des-
pair), there came a “gentle
rapping on my door”, & upon
looking up, I beheld a letter,
which the bearer said I
was entitled to, by right of super-
scription- My first thought was
that he had been sent by some
Evil Power to taunt me in my
distress, & I was about ex-
ecuting a thought which was
uppermost in my mind; viz:
throwing an old shoe at his
head; when I was attracted
by a certain air of inoffen-
siveness which his counten-
ance bore, and bidding him
to approach, upon closer in-
spection, found that the
letter was truly mine, and
from no other person than
yourself- Although it came too
late to prevent the deprida-
tions which I had committed
on my scalp, yet it served to
revive my drooping spirits & has
given me strength enough to write the foregoing-
And now, my precious lit-
tle, sweet-heart, promising
that the foregoing narrative
is to be allowed a certain
“margin,” I will proceed to say,
that through some accident,
to the deponent unknown, your
letter did not reach me till, to-day,
but as it was written on Fri-
day, I will not seek to complain.
It is enough to know that I
have a message from your
darling self, without the
necessity for any mur-
muring. You seem to have
had a very interesting
time recently, in your na-
tive city; such as atten-
ding marriage-ceremonies,
receptions, etc. I am al-
most afraid to venture down
that way, lest I may not
come away alone. Permit me,
right here & without farther
delay, to apologize for the
foregoing sentence, since I
am convinced, that on reading
it, so greatly would you be
offended, that you would refuse
to shake hands, should when, I
next come. Trusting that you
are somewhat paciefied, al-
low me to ask, why you
neglected to speak of Dr
Lewter's wedding, which oc-
curred on the 20th.? I should
have imagined that no such
important event had ever
transpired in the annals
of Murfreesboro, and that
y it would have deserved,
at least, a passing notice
from your pen. Was it
that your feelings -- well,
really, my darling E., pardon
this “lapsus pennae,” as I
have foregone the “style
ironical,” although it will
occasionally tingle on the
point of one's pen.

How long does Miss Bettie
Reed intend staying in Mur-
freesboro? I should like to
tease her a little, if she would
bear it. Now that the school-
girls are returning, your
town will again assume
its usual appearance of
activity, & many a heart
will “beat happily.” For instance,
with what a bright eye and
winsome smile will Miss
Laura S. greet the return
of the wandering Conrad!
Ah! “there are some happy mo-
ments in this lone and des-
olate world of ours, that well
repay the toil of struggling
through it, and atone for many
a long, sad night & weary day”!
'Tis thus I hear her exclaim!
And who knows but what some
maiden will cease her sighings
when she beholds the calm
look & commanding figure of
my esteemed friend, Sharp!
Come, cease your blushing; stran-
ger things have happened!
Ah! fortunate mortal! To have
won so fair a damsel, &
with so little show to the public,
is a feather in any man's cap!
But I must cease.
div1.closer:
Believe me, my darling Emilie,
more than ever, your fond & devoted Walter-
